Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
NSF Postdoctoral Fellowships in Biology combine research and training components to prepare young scientists for careers in emerging areas where biology intersects with other scientific disciplines, in this case with mathematics and physical sciences. The Fellows are expected to lead the nation?s scientific workforce of the future. This fellowship to John A. Marino supports research and training linking empirical and theoretical approaches to study and enhance ecological inference and forecasting, with applications to critical threats facing Great Lakes fisheries. The host institutions for this fellowship are Michigan State University and the University of Michigan, and the sponsoring scientists are Drs. Scott Peacor and Edward Ionides. Training goals include learning new analytical approaches and tools. Outreach efforts includes students and also non-government organizations, the public, fisheries managers, the commercial fishing and recreation industries, and policy makers.

Inference and prediction of population dynamics and species interactions are major ecological research goals, and recent methodological advances have vastly improved approaches to meet these goals. However, these methodologies have not yet been widely applied or well adapted for broad use in ecological research. This research develops an inference framework that has provided new and valuable insights in human disease for use more broadly in ecological research, especially with respect to aquatic ecosystems - fitting theoretical models of species interactions to ecological time series data. Using this approach, two critical problems affecting fisheries in the Laurentian Great Lakes are addressed: invasive species and global climate change. Specifically, the project examines hypothesized interactive effects on important prey fishes of two potential stresses: two major invasive species (dreissenid mussels and the spiny water flea, Bythotrephes longimanus), and the joint effects of the water flea and climate change.

ProgramElement.Text: Inters Biol and Math and Phys

ProgramReference.Text: POSTDOC FELLOW IN SCI, MATH EN

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to improve inference and prediction for dynamics in ecological systems, with a focus on food web interactions in the Great Lakes. This goal was accomplished through the use of cutting-edge analytical techniques: complex dynamic models fit to time series data using a recently developed algorithm, iterated filtering. Models (sets of equations) were developed to represent hypothesized interactions between crustacean zooplankton species in the Great Lakes, with a focus on effects of an invasive predator, Bythotrephes longimanus, on its native prey species. These models were fit to a long-term, seasonal time series (1994-2012) for offshore zooplankton collected by researchers at the NOAA-Great Lakes Environmental Research Laboratory. We also compared our approach to alternative statistical approaches (e.g., autoregressive models, which are often used to analyze time series data). Our results suggest that our approach performed substantially better than alternative approaches (i.e., provided a much better fit to the data without a substantial increase in the complexity of the model) and allowed us to quantify important biological rates and parameters. Our findings indicate that Bythotrephes strongly reduces the growth rate and biomass of its prey in Lake Michigan. Such effects may be important for important prey fish species (e.g., alewives), which share food resources with Bythotrephes. Furthermore, our model fits also quantified other important aspects of zooplankton ecology and the measurement process, including seasonal variation in zooplankton birth rates, mortality rates, random process variation, and measurement error. The project results thus provided new, valuable insights into the ecology of the Great Lakes food web and the impacts of a major threat to the Great Lakes, invasive species. The improved understanding of invasive species effects resulting from this work may have implications for better management of fisheries (which can depend critically on components of the lower food web) and policy (e.g., legislation regarding invasive species control). Finally, the application of these methods to food webs represents a major extension of these methods, which had previously been used primarily to analyze data for human disease dynamics. Due to their intrinsic complexity, many ecological systems could be better represented by complex models, which motivates the broader use of the approach adopted for this project. The project outcomes should thus allow for enhanced ecological inference and prediction.

The project supported the training of a postdoctoral fellow in statistical and computational approaches, building on his previous background in ecological research. In addition, the project supported mentorship by the fellow of an undergraduate researcher in ecology and statistics. The fellow was also involved in university efforts to increase representation of underrepresented groups in science at both the K-12 and undergraduate levels through outreach and curricular activities. Finally, as part of the project, the fellow initiated a new, interdisciplinary collaboration involving researchers at multiple institutions (University of Michigan, Michigan State University, Bradley University) and agencies (NOAA-Great Lakes Environmental Research Laboratory, USGS Great Lakes Science Center) to examine key stressors of Great Lakes food webs.

 


Last Modified: 02/06/2017
Modified by: John A Marino
